content.title: BitLayer's mainnet v1 is a sidechain
content.content: BitLayer is building towards a validia chain on top of Bitcoin. Its current implementation is a MPC protocol with 21, federated validators securing the network. It supports an EVM execution environment with plans to support other VMs. In its docs, BitLayer states that it will use an offchain data availability solution in its future mainnet releases. Its roadmap sees it adding support for a BitVM-style bridge, but currently, the bridge is managed by various multi-sig wallets.

content.title: Users trust centralized multi-sigs and upgradeable contracts with the custody of their BTC
content.content: Users can deposit BTC into two different centralized multi-sigs to interact with BitLayer. BTC users will deposit their BTC into a Bitcoin wallet that initiates an unlock transfer from a vault on the BitLayer chain. EVM users can deposit wBTC into BitLayer from their EVM wallet. Both bridge contracts are upgradeable multi-sigs. Users trust the operators of this multi-sig to not steal their funds.

content.title: Offchain via DAC
content.content: BitLayer currently stores its data off of the Bitcoin mainchain. We are reviewing the trust assumptions related to DA.

content.title: BitLayer is run a permissioned validator set
content.content: BitLayer is currently run by a MPC protocol with 21 federated validators securing the network. The operators of these validators are unknown. Although these validators would presumably stake BitLayer's native token, BTR, to secure the network, none of the active validator addresses currently hold any BTR tokens. These nodes are presumably responsible for data availability, block production and validating the state of the sidechain.

content.title: State validation mechanism in under review
BTR token likely used to incentivize validators
content.content: The BTR token is live on BitLayer and will likely be used to incentivize validators. Validators on BitLayer's mainnet v1 currently do not stake any token.

content.title: BitVM
content.content: The BitLayer team has an open repository of research related to BitVM. They are looking to build a trust-minimized bridge between BitLayer and Bitcoin.

content.title: Alternative DA
content.content: According to BitLayer’s docs, the team plans on using an alternative solution for data availability. Users would trust the consensus mechanism behind this solution instead of Bitcoin full nodes for the availability of data.

content.title: Ethereum Virtual Machine
content.content: BitLayer is built on a fork of geth, an Ethereum client. It leverges the Ethereum Virtual Machine, which is a software responsible for smart contract execution for a number of blockchains, namely the Ethereum Network. It uses Solidity/Vyper as its code and is the dominant environment for smart contract execution in the cryptocurrency ecosystem. Developer from Ethereum would have less difficulty deploying their applications on BitLayer compared to other execution environments.

content.title: Faster block times
content.content: BitLayer is currently producing blocks every three seconds which provides a better user experience than using the Bitcoin, or Ethereum, mainchains.

content.title: EVM-based applications
content.content: The potential usecases for BitLayer are similar to that of other EVM-based sidechains. Developers can deploy smart contracts that enable applications like borrowing and lending protocols, stablecoins, NFTs, and more. The primary, proposed use case for BitLayer is to act as an application layer for Bitcoin

content.title: BitLayer has a centralized operator
content.content: Block production is controlled by one operator. Users trust that the operator will be honest. They also trust that the operator will not reorder transactions to extract MEV.

content.title: Withdrawals take 3-7 days to process
content.content: Withdrawals from BitLayer to Bitcoin are permitted by a centralized operator and take 3-7 days to process
